deliberation: Checked the prophetic introduction formula. The clause 'the word of YHWH came to me' portrays God's message as an entity that 'comes' to the prophet. This is a conventional prophetic idiom that personifies the divine word as moving toward the prophet.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
vehicle: a 'word' that comes/arrives like a person or object
ground: the initiative and directedness of God's message toward the prophet
causal impact upon the prophet
experience of receiving revelation
posture: presenting revelation as vivid, active intervention
instances.explanation: The divine 'word' is depicted as if it were an entity that can 'come' to someone, a standard prophetic personification/idiom for receiving revelation.

deliberation: Examined titles, heart-language, and spatial phrases. Found several idiomatic/metaphorical expressions: 'son of man' as idiomatic title, 'your heart has been lifted up' as a metaphor for pride, 'seat of God' and 'heart of the seas' as images of exalted, secure rule, and 'you set your heart like the heart of God' as a simile for presumptuous self-deification.

instances.english_text: O mortal (lit. son of man)
ground: belonging to the class of 'man', finite and mortal
shared human limitations
anthropological status before God
posture: underscoring the prophet's humanity in contrast to the divine
instances.explanation: The phrase 'son of man' idiomatically means 'human being'. It uses descent terminology (son of X) as a synecdochic-idiomatic way to denote membership in the class 'man'.

instances.english_text: your heart has been haughty (lit. your heart has become high)
target: the inner attitude of the prince of Tyre
ground: self-exaltation and lifting oneself above others
status elevation and superiority
social and moral over-valuation of self
posture: divine condemnation of the king's arrogance
instances.explanation: The heart, representing the inner self, is said to become 'high', using spatial elevation as a metaphorical idiom for arrogant pride.

instances.english_text: I sit on the seat of God
target: the royal position and claims of the prince of Tyre
ground: supreme, absolute authority and exalted status
unassailable power and honor
quasi-divine sovereignty
posture: ironically echoing the king's self-exalting claim for the purpose of judgment
instances.explanation: The human ruler's throne is described as 'the seat of God', metaphorically elevating his political position to a divine throne, expressing his presumptuous claim to godlike authority.

instances.english_text: in the heart of the seas
target: the geographical and political situation of Tyre and its ruler
ground: centrality, depth, and (apparent) invulnerability surrounded by waters
inaccessibility and remoteness
perceived security of an island fortress
posture: highlighting the king's sense of being securely enthroned beyond human reach
descriptive but in service of critique
instances.explanation: Tyre's location is described as the 'heart of the seas', using the heart as a metaphor for the innermost, central, and thus supposedly secure position.

instances.english_text: and you deemed your heart like the heart of God
target: the king of Tyre's self-understanding and will
ground: claim to possess godlike insight, authority, and independence
equality with or rivalry toward God
usurpation of divine prerogatives
posture: explicitly condemning the king’s presumption to likeness with God
instances.explanation: The ruler is said to have made his 'heart' (inner self) 'like the heart of God', an explicit simile expressing his arrogant claim to a divine-level mind and authority.

deliberation: Considered whether the comparison with Daniel and the claim that no secret is hidden is simply evaluative or rhetorically exaggerated. The statement that no hidden thing is obscure to him is an exaggeration, and within the judgment context it functions with biting irony.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנֵּ֥ה חָכָ֛ם אַתָּ֖ה ... כׇּל־סָת֖וּם לֹ֥א עֲמָמֽוּךָ
instances.english_text: Yes, you are wiser than Daniel; in no hidden matter can anyone compare to you.
target: the king of Tyre's reputed wisdom and insight
vehicle: knowing every hidden thing, surpassing even Daniel
ground: extraordinary cleverness and success in uncovering or exploiting secrets
practical shrewdness far above normal rulers
overblown claim to unrivaled wisdom
posture: sarcastic echoing of the king’s self-estimate to expose his folly
instances.explanation: Saying that no hidden matter is obscure to him and that he surpasses even Daniel overstates his wisdom and, in the judgment context, functions as ironic hyperbole exposing his arrogance.

deliberation: The verse describes gaining wealth by wisdom and understanding and storing gold and silver in treasuries. These are straightforward descriptions of economic success, with no marked figurative expressions beyond normal lexical usage.

Checked commercial language and heart-language. The commercial terms are literal. The only marked figurative expression is again the idiom of the 'heart' being lifted up as a metaphor for pride caused by wealth.

instances.english_text: and your heart grew haughty because of your wealth (lit. your heart was lifted up in your wealth)
target: the king’s inner attitude shaped by his riches
human pride rooted in material success
ground: self-elevation and inflated self-importance
rising above proper limits in one's own estimation
arrogant overconfidence
instances.explanation: The inner self ('heart') is said to be 'lifted up', using spatial height as an idiomatic metaphor for becoming proud on account of wealth.

deliberation: Reiterates the accusation that he made his heart like the heart of God. This is the same simile/metaphor of presumptuous self-deification noted in v.2, now in God's judicial pronouncement.

instances.english_text: Because you have deemed your heart like the heart of God
target: the king's self-estimation and volitional center
ground: claim to godlike wisdom, authority, and autonomy
overstepping the creaturely boundary
self-deifying arrogance
posture: God's explicit statement of the king’s culpable presumption
instances.explanation: The king is said to have made his heart 'like the heart of God', again using an explicit simile to express an arrogant claim to a divine-level mind and status.

deliberation: Looked at 'strangers, ruthless nations', and the attack on 'the beauty of your wisdom' and 'your splendor'. The invaders' swords cannot literally strike abstract wisdom and splendor; these abstractions stand metonymically for the king and his whole glorious state.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהֵרִ֤יקוּ חַרְבוֹתָם֙ עַל־יְפִ֣י חׇכְמָתֶ֔ךָ וְחִלְּל֖וּ יִפְעָתֶֽךָ
instances.english_text: They shall unsheathe their swords against the beauty of your wisdom, and they shall profane your splendor.
target: the king of Tyre’s person and his entire glorious kingdom
vehicle: the 'beauty of your wisdom' and 'your splendor'
ground: his renowned sophistication and magnificent court being what will be overthrown
his glory as the essence of his regime
publicly visible excellence subject to violent humiliation
posture: foretelling a humiliating end to his celebrated brilliance
instances.explanation: The 'beauty of your wisdom' and 'your splendor' function as metonymy for the king himself and his magnificent regime, which the invaders’ swords will in fact destroy.

deliberation: Considered death imagery and spatial phrases. The descent to 'the Pit' is standard metaphor for going to the underworld/grave, and 'in the heart of the seas' repeats the metaphorical centrality/embeddedness of Tyre even in its death scene.

instances.english_text: They shall bring you down to the Pit
target: the king of Tyre’s death and downfall
ground: transition from exaltation to a low, powerless state
burial and exclusion from the realm of the living
irreversible humiliation and destruction
posture: depicting death as a humiliating descent
instances.explanation: Death is portrayed as being brought down into 'the Pit', a conventional metaphor/idiom for the grave or underworld, emphasizing a fall from height to depth.

instances.english_text: in the heart of the seas
target: the location and context of the king’s demise
Tyre’s position as a maritime power
vehicle: central core of a body used for spatial location
ground: being engulfed/encircled by the sea, yet now to die there
central but ultimately vulnerable position
from apparent invulnerability to exposed ruin
posture: ironically reusing the earlier boast of secure location as the scene of death
instances.explanation: As in v.2, 'the heart of the seas' uses the heart as a metaphor for the center of the waters; here it underscores that even in that seemingly secure position he will die a violent death.

deliberation: The verse stages a rhetorical question contrasting the king’s claim 'I am a god' with his imminent death. The rhetoric is sharp but the language itself is not cast in metaphor, simile, or idiom beyond literal usage; it contrasts literal deity with literal mortality.

The phrase 'death of the uncircumcised' evokes cultural shame but is a literal characterization of the kind of death (like that of pagan foreigners). No clear metaphor or other figure beyond straightforward description.
Same prophetic introductory formula as v.1. Again, the 'word' of YHWH is portrayed as coming to the prophet, personifying the divine message and functioning as a standard idiom.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
target: YHWH’s communication initiating a new oracle
ground: the active, initiated character of revelation directed to the prophet
impact of God’s message upon the human recipient
experience of receiving speech as an intrusion
posture: framing the oracle as divinely originated
instances.explanation: As in v.1, the divine 'word' is personified as an entity that 'comes' to Ezekiel, a conventional prophetic idiom.

deliberation: Looked at the lament instruction and the description of the king. The key figurative expression is 'you were the seal of perfection', a metaphor comparing the king to a seal that embodies and stamps out a perfect pattern. 'Full of wisdom, perfect in beauty' extends the idealizing imagery but is less structurally figurative.

instances.english_text: You were the seal of perfection
target: the idealized status of the king of Tyre before his fall
vehicle: a 'seal' that embodies a perfect pattern
ground: being the standard or exemplar that imprints a pattern
embodying and representing perfection in a definitive way
serving as the model of complete wisdom and beauty
posture: elevating the king’s former status in order to heighten the tragedy of his fall
instances.explanation: The king is compared to a 'seal of perfection', metaphorically portraying him as the definitive stamp of an ideal pattern of wisdom and beauty.

deliberation: Assessed Eden imagery and gemstone list. Being 'in Eden, the garden of God' is mythic language applied to a human king, a metaphorical relocation to a primordial divine garden. 'Every precious stone was your adornment' is idealized, borderline hyperbolic, but mainly continues the Edenic/metaphorical portrayal.

instances.english_text: You were in Eden, the garden of God
target: the original exalted condition of the king of Tyre
ground: delight, abundance, and proximity to the divine
pristine, unspoiled blessedness
a setting of supreme beauty and privilege
posture: casting the king’s rise in mythic, Edenic terms to contrast with his fall
instances.explanation: The king is said to have been 'in Eden, the garden of God', relocating his royal prosperity into the imagery of the primordial divine garden, a metaphor for ideal blessedness and proximity to God.

instances.english_text: Every precious stone was your adornment
target: the king’s magnificent adornment and wealth
vehicle: every precious stone as his covering
ground: overwhelming richness and beauty of his regalia
nothing lacking in his ornamental splendor
superlative, all-encompassing luxury
posture: accentuating his former glory to underscore the greatness of his fall
instances.explanation: The statement that 'every precious stone' was his adornment overstates the king’s jeweled regalia to convey superlative luxury, functioning as hyperbolic idealization.

deliberation: The verse portrays the addressee as an anointed cherub on God's holy mountain, walking among 'stones of fire'. Read within a human-address context, this is an extended metaphor mapping the king onto a heavenly guardian figure dwelling in a cosmic sanctuary.

instances.hebrew_text: אַתְּ־כְּר֔וּב מִמְשַׁ֖ח הַסּוֹכֵ֑ךְ ... בְּהַ֨ר קֹ֤דֶשׁ אֱלֹהִים֙ הָיִ֔יתָ בְּת֥וֹךְ אַבְנֵי־אֵ֖שׁ הִתְהַלָּֽכְתָּ
instances.english_text: I created you as a cherub with outstretched shielding wings; and you resided on God’s holy mountain; you walked among stones of fire.
target: the exalted status and role of the king of Tyre before his fall
royal guardianship and proximity to the divine
vehicle: an anointed, shielding cherub on God’s mountain among fiery stones
heavenly throne guardian dwelling in a blazing sanctuary
ground: privileged access to the divine realm and protective responsibility
exalted, sacred status above ordinary mortals
radiant glory and dangerous holiness
posture: mythologizing the king’s role to dramatize the height from which he will fall
prophetic use of cosmic imagery to interpret political reality
instances.explanation: The human king is depicted as an 'anointed cherub' stationed on God’s holy mountain and walking among fiery stones, an extended metaphor for his exalted, sacral guardianship near the divine presence.

deliberation: Looked for lexical/metaphorical patterns. 'In your ways' is a standard biblical metaphor where 'ways' or paths represent conduct/behavior. 'From the day you were created' is temporal, not obviously figurative in this context.

instances.english_text: You were blameless in your ways
target: the king’s patterns of conduct in his initial state
vehicle: ‘ways’ as paths or roads one travels
ground: behavior as a course one follows through life
consistency and directionality of one’s conduct
moral quality mapped onto path imagery
posture: evaluating the king’s former conduct in positive terms before corruption
instances.explanation: The word 'ways' metaphorically depicts his conduct as paths he travels, a common idiom equating a life-course with a traveled way.

deliberation: Continues the cherub/mountain imagery from vv. 14–15. God 'profanes' him from the mountain of God and destroys him as the 'shielding cherub,' keeping the extended metaphor of a heavenly guardian being expelled from a sacred mountain.

instances.hebrew_text: וָאֲחַלֶּלְךָ֩ מֵהַ֨ר אֱלֹהִ֤ים וָֽאַבֶּדְךָ֙ כְּר֣וּב הַסֹּכֵ֔ךְ מִתּ֖וֹךְ אַבְנֵי־אֵֽשׁ
instances.english_text: So I have profaned you from the mountain of God, and I have destroyed you, O shielding cherub, from among the stones of fire.
target: the king of Tyre’s removal from his exalted, sacralized position
vehicle: a cherub expelled from God’s mountain and fiery stones
guardian being removed from a holy, fiery realm
ground: loss of access to the divine presence and protective office
being stripped of holiness and privilege
radical demotion from sacred heights
posture: depicting the judgment as a profanation of one once deemed holy
instances.explanation: The king’s downfall is expressed via the ongoing metaphor of a 'shielding cherub' expelled from God’s mountain and fiery realm, signaling loss of sacral status and nearness to God.

deliberation: Noted the recurrent 'heart lifted up' idiom, and the casting to the earth. Both use spatial metaphors: elevation of the heart for pride, and being thrown to the earth for humiliation and removal from the heavenly-like status created in prior verses.

instances.english_text: Your heart grew haughty because of your beauty (lit. your heart was lifted up in your beauty)
target: the king’s inner attitude shaped by his physical/royal beauty
ground: self-exaltation on account of perceived attractiveness/glory
rising above one’s proper place in one’s own estimation
arrogant, beauty-based hubris
posture: condemning the corrupting effect of his beauty on his character
instances.explanation: Again the 'heart' is said to be lifted up, a metaphor for arrogance, here specifically rooted in his beauty.

instances.hebrew_text: עַל־אֶ֣רֶץ הִשְׁלַכְתִּ֗יךָ לִפְנֵ֧י מְלָכִ֛ים נְתַתִּ֖יךָ לְרַ֥אֲוָה בָֽךְ
instances.english_text: I have cast you to the ground; I have made you an object for kings to stare at.

shameful display before peers
public humiliation after former glory
posture: intentionally dramatizing his humiliation as a cautionary spectacle
instances.explanation: The king’s downfall is depicted as being hurled to the earth and made a spectacle before other kings, a metaphor for extreme humiliation after exaltation.

deliberation: Focused on 'I brought out fire from your midst; it consumed you; I made you ashes.' Given the personal addressee and prior cosmic imagery, 'fire from within you' is best read metaphorically as judgment arising from his own corruption, rather than simply literal city-burning, though that may be the historical referent.

instances.english_text: So I made a fire issue from you, and it has devoured you.
target: the destructive judgment that overtakes the king/kingdom of Tyre
vehicle: a fire emerging from within and consuming the person
internal blaze that devours its source
ground: his own sins and violence generating the disaster that destroys him
judgment that arises from within the very system it ruins
inescapable, consuming consequences
posture: emphasizing the self-originating nature of his punishment
instances.explanation: The judgment is depicted as a fire coming out from within him that consumes him, a metaphor for destruction generated by his own accumulated guilt and violence.

deliberation: Considered whether 'you have become a horror' is literal or figurative. Calling the king 'a horror/terror' is a metaphor: he himself turns into an object that evokes shuddering in those who see his fate.

instances.english_text: You have become a horror
target: the remembered fate and reputation of the king/kingdom
ground: evoking shock, dread, and desolation in observers
serving as a chilling example of judgment
eliciting appalled response rather than admiration
posture: framing his fate as a cautionary spectacle
instances.explanation: The king is said to 'become a horror', metaphorically turning his person/legacy into an object that causes terror and astonishment among the nations.

deliberation: Same prophetic narrative formula as vv.1 and 11. Again the 'word of YHWH' is depicted as coming to the prophet, a personifying idiom for reception of revelation.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
target: YHWH’s communication inaugurating a new oracle about Sidon
vehicle: a 'word' that comes/arrives at a person
ground: the active initiative of God’s message reaching the prophet
experience of revelation as an incursion
message as something that can newly appear
instances.explanation: The divine 'word' is again personified as coming to Ezekiel, a fixed idiom in prophetic literature.

deliberation: Examined the command formula. 'Set your face toward Sidon' is a common prophetic idiom, using the physical act of turning the face as a metaphor for determined focus or opposition.

instances.english_text: Set your face toward Sidon
target: Ezekiel’s prophetic attention and stance toward Sidon
ground: firmly directing oneself toward an object of concern
resolved confrontation or engagement
non-physical orientation toward a task/target
posture: summoning the prophet to intentional, confrontational proclamation
instances.explanation: Commanding Ezekiel to 'set your face toward Sidon' uses bodily orientation as a metaphorical idiom for resolute attention and hostile prophetic engagement.

deliberation: Looked at 'I am against you', 'I will be glorified in your midst', and 'I will be sanctified in her.' The key idiom here is 'hineni alayikh'—literally 'I am upon you'—used as a metaphorical idiom for hostile opposition. The glory/sanctification language is cultic-theological but not structurally figurative in itself.

instances.english_text: I am going to deal with you (lit. Here I am against/over you), O Sidon
target: YHWH’s hostile stance and impending action against Sidon
vehicle: being 'upon' someone (עַל) in a confrontational sense
ground: standing over against as an adversary ready to strike
overpowering, dominating posture
hostile engagement
posture: announcing direct divine enmity against Sidon
instances.explanation: The phrase 'hineni alayikh' literally means 'here I am upon you' but idiomatically expresses God’s being against Sidon as an enemy, using spatial over-againstness as a metaphor for hostile opposition.

deliberation: Considered pestilence, blood, and sword language. Pestilence and bloodshed are literal calamities. 'The sword comes upon her from all sides' uses 'sword' as a metonym for invading warfare and armed enemies.

instances.english_text: when the sword comes upon her from all sides
ground: the essential role of swords/weapons in warfare
killing and destruction associated with metal blades
violent, lethal conflict
instances.explanation: The 'sword' stands metonymically for hostile armies and warfare that will surround and strike Sidon.

deliberation: This verse clearly uses plant-thorn imagery in a figurative way: neighbors who despise Israel are described as a 'prickling brier' and 'painful thorn.' These are metaphors for hostile, irritating neighbors whose attacks wound Israel.

instances.hebrew_text: סִלּ֤וֹן מַמְאִיר֙ וְק֣וֹץ מַכְאִ֔ב מִכֹּל֙ סְבִ֣יבֹתָ֔ם הַשָּׁאטִ֖ים אוֹתָ֑ם
instances.english_text: a prickling brier and lacerating thorn from all around them who despise them
target: the hostile neighboring peoples around Israel
vehicle: a prickling brier and a painful thorn
ground: causing ongoing pain, irritation, and injury when in close contact
being hard to remove and constantly harmful
surrounding, vexing presence
posture: portraying Israel’s neighbors as harmful irritants soon to be removed
prophetic promise of liberation from harassment
instances.explanation: The despising neighbors are compared to 'a prickling brier and a painful thorn', metaphorically depicting their hostility as constant, wounding irritation to Israel.

deliberation: Describes gathering Israel from the nations and settling them on their land. 'Gathering' and 'settling' are straightforward in the exile-return context; the language is primarily literal, with no marked metaphors or idioms beyond normal usage.

Describes dwelling securely, building houses, planting vineyards, and God executing judgments on those who despised them. These are concrete markers of peace and restoration; though they can function symbolically, here they are expressed literally without clear figurative framing within the verse.
